comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
On the Royal Welch Fusiliers website Fermoy is mentioned repeatedly.  "On the 24th August 1887 the 2nd Battalion moved from Fermoy to Galway, finding detachments at Castlebar, Oughterard and Gort. 
On the 2nd Battalion leaving the following complimentary 'resolution'was received from the Magistrates of Fermoy:-
"Resolved: that we the Magistrates assembled at Fermoy Petty Sessions, beg to record our unanimous approval of the conduct of the Royal Welch Fusiliers while stationed here for the past two years, their (sic) not being, to the best of our recollection, a civil case against them during that period, and that our clerk be directed to send a copy of this resolution to Col. Williamson, in command of the regiment.
Signed Geo Montgomery,
Chairman
Fermoy Petty Sessions, 12th September 1887
From reading through their site it appears that they left in 1887 and went to Galway where they remained for some time.
As I remember it the big open field behind became the grounds of the aerodrome that was attached to the camp and used up to quite recently.  The mighty Munster team that beat the New Zealand All Blacks in 1978 trained on that field in the run up to the historic match.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 
be flattered...it's so fabulous I've had to share!  
Surely you're familiar with the rather...er...rigid nature of many librarians.  This reminds me of the way I label my photos (both for work & my own).
